awd_titl_txt: Formation of rain layers in the Warm Pool and their feedbacks to atmospheric convection in an idealized modeling framework
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the warm tropical ocean, the supply of moist air sets up convective systems which manifest themselves in rainfall as a pattern of wet and dry spells, each lasting 30 to 60 days and propagating slowly Eastward. Within this so-called Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO), the understanding of ocean feedback processes to atmospheric convection remains incomplete, and hinders its representation in climate and forecast models. The MJO is sensitive to upper ocean stability, because a stable surface ocean does not mix as readily or deeply, which makes it easier to generate larger temperature anomalies within a shallow surface layer through solar heating or evaporative cooling. This effect has been studied more with warm surface layers, but thin layers of relatively fresh water often formed by rainfall can also enhance stability of the surface layer. Because these layers tend to be small and ephemeral, they have not been studied as much. This project will use a regional atmospheric model coupled with a simplified model of the upper ocean to explore the impacts of rain layers on atmospheric convection. In addition to better understanding MJO mechanisms, the project will introduce a new model for investigating air-sea interactions, and novel analyses of ocean feedbacks to atmospheric convection. The project will also enable collaboration between atmospheric and oceanographic scientists, support for female scientists, and graduate education.

Studies during the past decade have advanced our understanding of the importance of diurnal warm layers (DWLs) for the onset of the MJO, how MJO convection and wind anomalies interact with the upper ocean heat content, and have documented the evolution of large- scale sea surface salinity (SSS) patterns shaped by MJO rainfall. Less clear, however, is how the formation of transient ocean surface freshwater lenses, or rain layers (RLs), may temper ocean mixing, marine surface fluxes, and MJO convection. RLs are typically more buoyant and colder than Warm Pool surface waters, producing a cold patch on the ocean surface. Because RLs are shallow (0.5 - 5 m) and short-lived (< 1 day), they are likely undersampled by in situ observing systems. Direct observations of RLs in the Warm Pool are sparse, and efforts to document their observed spatial and temporal characteristics are in their infancy. The frequency, intensity, and duration of RLs, and their effects on atmospheric convection throughout the MJO lifecycle are largely unknown. A collection of rain layers generated by widespread convection would reduce surface latent and sensible heat fluxes via SST cooling, but would also generate a fine-scale network of sharp SST gradients, which have been linked to convective initiation. This study will use the Regional Atmospheric Modeling System (RAMS) coupled to many columns of a 1-dimensional KPP ocean mixed layer model 1) to study the formation of upper ocean stable layers by surface heating and freshening, including their frequency, spatial variability, and duration, and their regulation of upper ocean stability and mixing, and 2) to study how rain layers may interact with convection during the MJO suppressed-to-active transition period. Model-generated stable layer statistics will be compared to previously published ocean observations collected during the DYNAMO field campaign. Ocean feedbacks to convection will be assessed through a progression of diagnostics designed to link variations in upper ocean stability to surface fluxes and the organization of tropical convection.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fresh rainwater that falls onto the salty ocean floats on the ocean surface because it is less dense than ocean water. The rain-ocean density difference is so large that it can temporarily prevent mixing of the ocean surface layers with the deeper ocean layers. Formation of these so-called rain lenses has been observed during special field measurement campaigns, but their effects on the ocean surface temperature and subsequent influence of these ocean surface temperatures on the development of clouds in the atmosphere has not been investigated in detail. 

 

The first part of this project studied how these rain lenses affected spatial patterns of ocean surface temperature and the vertical mixing of heat to the deeper ocean using a simple ocean mixing model driven by a month’s worth of realistic weather over a 50 km x 50 km domain in the tropical Indian Ocean. Our approach was to run the model twice: once where rain was allowed to fall onto the ocean surface, and once where it was not. In the first experiment, we found that rain lenses can last for up to about a day as long as surface winds are less than about 10 m/s, consistent with observations. Comparing results from both experiments led to a new finding that rain lenses, which start out cooler than the ocean surface (because the rain is cooler), cool even further for several hours as cooling from wind-driven evaporation remains trapped in the rain lenses and leads to increased “patchiness” of the ocean sea surface temperature pattern.

 

The second part of this project studied how rain lens-affected changes to ocean sea surface temperature patterns and the vertical distribution of ocean heat influence cloud formation over the tropical ocean during a one-month period. For this part of the study, we used a new combination of an ocean model and an atmospheric model that allows the two to interact with one another, as in nature. This study covered a larger domain in the Indian Ocean (1000 km x 1000 km) and was forced with observed large-scale wind, temperature, and humidity fields in the atmosphere, and large-scale current, temperature, and salinity fields in the ocean. This approach ensures that mean conditions averaged over the entire domain evolve similarly to observations, but the fine-scale details and patterns evolve more freely. As before, we ran two experiments: one with rain falling onto the ocean, and one without. 

 

Before running these experiments, we thought that the main effect of rain lenses would be an increase in shallow clouds during light rainfall conditions due to the increased patchiness of warm and cold ocean surface temperature patterns. While this effect was seen in our experiments, we found that a more important effect of rain lenses occured when cloud populations were transitioning from mostly shallow to mostly deep clouds. Compared to the experiment without rain falling onto the ocean, widespread rain lenses during this transition cooled the ocean surface, reduced cloud cover, and thereby trapped subsurface ocean heat from solar radiation below the rain lenses. With the arrival of strong winds, the rain lenses were destroyed, releasing the stored ocean heat to the atmosphere and leading to more vigorous atmospheric convection than in the no-rain experiment. These results show that rain lenses can delay the onset of deep tropical convection but cause it to be more vigorous once it develops.

 

The intellectual merit of this project is that it used a new model configuration to yield new insights into how the ocean and atmosphere interact with one another in the tropics. Broader impacts of the work are that presentations of our findings cultivated interdisciplinary interactions between atmospheric scientists and oceanographers. It also supported the training of one graduate student who has acquired analysis, modeling, and interdisciplinary thinking skills through the course of this work.
